messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 67 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Discounting in Strategy Logic

Paper Abstract: Abstract Discounting is an important dimension in multi-agent systems as long as we want to reason about strategies and time. It is a key aspect in economics as it captures the intuition that the far-away future is not as important as the near future. Traditional verification techniques allow to check whether there is a winning strategy for a group of agents but they do not take into account the fact that satisfying a goal sooner is different from satisfying it after a long wait. In this paper, we augment Strategy Logic with future discounting over a set of discounted functions ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}, denoted SLdisc‚Äã[ùíü]superscriptSLdiscdelimited-[]ùíü\textnormal{{SL}}^{\text{disc}}[\mathcal{D}]. We consider ‚Äúuntil‚Äù operators with discounting functions: the satisfaction value of a specification in SLdisc‚Äã[ùíü]superscriptSLdiscdelimited-[]ùíü\textnormal{{SL}}^{\text{disc}}[\mathcal{D}] is a value in [0,1]01[0,1], where the longer it takes to fulfill requirements, the smaller the satisfaction value is. We motivate our approach with classical examples from Game Theory and study the complexity of model-checking SLdisc‚Äã[ùíü]superscriptSLdiscdelimited-[]ùíü\textnormal{{SL}}^{\text{disc}}[\mathcal{D}]-formulas.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 67 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 67"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "On the theory of infinitely repeated games with discounting",
        "Model-checking for resource-bounded ATL with production and consumption of resources",
        "On the complexity of resource-bounded logics",
        "Discounting in LTL",
        "Formally reasoning about quality",
        "Alternating-time temporal logic",
        "Prompt alternating-time epistemic logics",
        "Secretary problems: weights and discounts",
        "Bisimulations for verifying strategic abilities with an application to threeballot",
        "Verification of multi-agent systems with public actions against strategy logic",
        "Strategy logic with imperfect information",
        "Synthesis from LTL specifications with mean-payoff objectives",
        "Infinite runs in weighted timed automata with energy constraints",
        "Averaging in LTL",
        "Reasoning about quality and fuzziness of strategic behaviours",
        "Reasoning about quality and fuzziness of strategic behaviors",
        "Timed concurrent game structures",
        "Combining quantitative and qualitative reasoning in concurrent multi-player games",
        "Practical verification of multi-agent systems against SLK specifications",
        "Resource interfaces",
        "Strategy Logic",
        "Automatic verification of competitive stochastic systems",
        "Handbook of model checking, volume 10",
        "Discounting the future in systems theory",
        "Model checking discounted temporal properties",
        "Online approval committee elections",
        "Positional strategies for mean payoff games",
        "Model checking intelligent avionics systems for test cases generation using multi-agent systems",
        "Tree automata, mu-calculus and determinacy",
        "Multi-issue negotiation with deadlines",
        "Assume-guarantee synthesis for prompt linear temporal logic",
        "Competitive Markov Decision Processes",
        "The secretary problem and its extensions: A review",
        "Nash and perfect equilibria of discounted repeated games",
        "The folk theorem in repeated games with discounting or with incomplete information",
        "Automata, logics, and infinite games: a guide to current research, volume 2500",
        "Equilibria for games with combined qualitative and quantitative objectives",
        "Delay discounting and performance on the prisoner‚Äôs dilemma game",
        "Timed alternating-time temporal logic",
        "Multi-valued verification of strategic ability",
        "Natural strategic abilities in voting protocols",
        "A temporal logic for markov chains",
        "A temporal logic for stochastic multi-agent systems",
        "An automata-theoretic approach to branching-time model checking",
        "Petri net based multi-robot task coordination from temporal logic specifications",
        "Model-checking timed.",
        "The role of time in negotiations",
        "Social discounting and the prisoner‚Äôs dilemma game",
        "Formal specification and verification of autonomous robotic systems: A survey",
        "Weighted LTL with discounting",
        "Strategic reasoning in automated mechanism design",
        "Auction description language (ADL): General framework for representing auction-based markets",
        "Automated synthesis of mechanisms",
        "Reasoning about strategies: On the model-checking problem",
        "Alternating automata on infinite trees",
        "Algorithmic Game Theory",
        "Logic for mechanism design‚Äìa manifesto",
        "Repeated games with incomplete information and discounting",
        "The temporal logic of programs",
        "Perfect equilibrium in a bargaining model",
        "Stochastic games",
        "Automata on infinite objects",
        "A survey of smart contract formal specification and verification",
        "An automata-theoretic approach to automatic program verification",
        "On the complexity of model-checking branching and alternating-time temporal logics in one-counter systemss",
        "Two-person bargaining behavior in fixed discounting factors games with infinite horizon",
        "The complexity of mean payoff games on graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 67 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Discounting in Strategy Logic, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
